posts.name: Ryan Yohnk
posts.cooked:
Hey CD,

I‚Äôm prepping a lesson for our students on encoders and ran into something I‚Äôm not understanding. Hoping this group can point me in the right direction.

We‚Äôre easing our way into swerve drive and starting with utilizing encoders to track the angular position of the wheel. We‚Äôre using the VersaPlanetary Integrated Encoder which utilizes the CTR Electronics SRX Magnetic Encoder . All of this is plugged into a breakout board on the Talon SRX that controls angular movement.

I‚Äôm able to get the wheel to spin to desired angles without much fuss. The issues I‚Äôm unable to figure out is how to persist some type of orientation over a reboot. In the swerve drive case this would be to initialize them all to the same direction.

In our code I‚Äôve set the encoder type to ‚ÄúCTRE_MagEncoder_Absolute‚Äù. I‚Äôve also set the desired angle to 0 which translates to a 0 reading from the encoders.

I start up the robot, enable teleop, and let the wheel spin to 0. Then I unplug the speed controller (simulating a robot shutdown), plug it back in, and reenable teleop. The wheel then spins to a different heading, but never more than a 360 degree rotation.

Noting that absolute position is provided over PWM, I‚Äôve tested both the ‚ÄúgetSelectedSensorPosition‚Äù and ‚ÄúgetPulseWidthPosition‚Äù but I see both of them ‚Äúreset‚Äù when I unplug the motor.

Any thoughts on where I‚Äôm going wrong trying to get the absolute position of the encoder?

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Try using the getPulseWidth methods, the RiseToFall one will give you the raw value of the absolute position in a scale of 0-16384.

posts.name: Ryan Yohnk
posts.cooked:
Switch to the code over to use ‚ÄúgetPulseWidthRiseToFallUs‚Äù and still not getting great results.

It will settle on one point and things seem to behave between reboots. But if I disable the robot, manually spin the wheel, and restart it then it will find a new 0 point.

EDIT: And fwiw, seems that a full rotation is 4096 not 16384.

posts.name: Cory
posts.cooked:
I would take some self-test snapshots at key points to see how they compare. You say your process is boot, spin to 0, power-cycle, spin to 0 again. Take a snapshot between each step and see if it makes sense. If you want, post them here and we can help further.

Also, I‚Äôm curious what the mechanical portion looks like. It‚Äôs in a versaplanetary integrated encoder, is it the last stage? Is there a reduction after the versa?

My first guess is that the absolute position is working fine, but after the power cycle it got nudged such that it wraps and is now nearly a full rotation off. If there is a reduction after the encoder, this makes it less obvious this is happening. The snapshots should reveal if this is happening, and if it isn‚Äôt they help provide other information that‚Äôs relevant.

posts.name: Ryan Yohnk
posts.cooked:
Did some more digging and it does look like an error on my part.

The encoder is on the bottom stack of the versa planetary gear box, so I was assuming the gear ratio was 1:1. What I wasn‚Äôt accounting for is the gear that rotates the Thrifty Swerve seems to be in a 5:1 ratio. So no getting around that.

With that in mind, I do see the encoder reading hit about zero five times per rotation. I think the randomness I perceived before was it just finding the closest zero.

Interesting problem now on how to automatically find a consistent set point. I‚Äôd love to hear if other have thoughts on how to accomplish this.

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked: The cheap and easy way is to add an index sensor.  This could be a limit switch on the chassis activated by a spur on the rotating module, or a reflection sensor picking up a sharpie mark or bit of retroreflective tape.  Just rotate in either direction until you find the index, then use the encoder to find the actual spot.

posts.name: Roger Moore
posts.cooked:
Why did you choose the VP Encoder slice?

There appears to be a mount for a mag encoder that is 1:1 with module external to the VP.

posts.name: Ryan Yohnk
posts.cooked: Love the idea. Maybe find a good use for all of the beam break sensors we have laying around

posts.name: Ryan Yohnk
posts.cooked: Great call. This is pure experimentation at the moment, and I didn‚Äôt even notice there was an optional ‚Äúencoder gear‚Äù. Right now ours does not have that installed. Probably the ‚Äúright‚Äù way to go.

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked:
For future reference, this is shown on pages 10 & 11 of the Thrifty Swerve Assembly Guide

There‚Äôs an ‚Äòoutboard‚Äô spot for the large encoder gear and an ‚Äòalternative inboard‚Äô spot as well. You‚Äôll want to pick one of them & mount the encoder accordingly as it gives you 1:1 positioning with the rotation of the wheel module. The encoder + case can mount on the underside of the main base plate or the top side of the motor plate depending on which side you press the magnet in on the encoder gear.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Vaguely unrelated, but does the thread locker not damage the plastics around there?

posts.name: Ryan Dognaux
posts.cooked: The case is 3D printed from Onyx. I haven‚Äôt seen any damage so far.

posts.name: R.C.
posts.cooked: Would def recommend plastic safe loctite. Makes it easy for students.
